message:
The `TaskScheduler` is one way in which `StartNew` and `ContinueWith` are unsafe. They also do not understand `async` delegates and have non-ideal default option values. But if you always pass a scheduler (e.g., `TaskScheduler.Default`) and specify the options you want (e.g., `DenyChildAttach`) and properly handle `async` delegates (e.g., `Unwrap` when necessary), then you can use `StartNew` and `ContinueWith` correctly.

But why would you want to? You'd be adding a lot of code just to do what `Task.Run` already does for you.
